Never one to go on at length.
Benson was a straight shooter with careful aim.
Harry Cockel represented agriculture, a splendid researcher who had been able to attend A&M as an undergraduate living in the project houses during the Depression.
with a good Germanic sense of humor and determination.
He carried a big volume of influence because of the depth and breadth of agriculture, including the college
experiment station, and extension service.
Yet Harry looked at what was good for the university first.
Dave Maxwell, a comparatively thin man who lived a little more than a block away from us
just beyond Southwest Berkway, led the College of Liberal Arts, which was growing rapidly, and he too had high esteem among his colleagues.
Mac Prescott, a tireless biochemist,
had come over from that department located in the College of Agriculture to head science.
No one was more determined to move his group forward
than Mack, a former World War II Air Force crew member in the Pacific with a long and strong record of accomplishment in biochemistry.

Dr. Alvin Price, in veterinary medicine, quote, slick owl, quote, to decades of students, was nearing the end of his splendid service, leading one of the nation's largest programs in veterinary medicine, but he too
was a splendid veteran.
Similarly, Ed Romanek, a comparatively unique Chicagoan, was the Dean of Architecture.
And he always brightened up the sessions with his humor.
Frank Hubert, who had been the Dean of Arts and Sciences before that unit was broken apart, now headed Education.

Field of view was campus wide on many points and statewide on some.

and Geosciences, I cannot remember the name right now of that dean, also was growing particularly in its national reputation in the fields of geology, geophysics, oceanography, and meteorology.
Paragraph, thus there were no dark corners nor dead centers in the group.
During the Calhoun years, paragraph, during the Calhoun years as dean of faculties,
It was my task to lead a number of the searches for Dean's and other key administrative slots.
The first of those came when Dean Price retired from veterinary medicine.
Being a naive and inexperienced
chairman of a search committee, I was part of a decision to interview eight finalists for that post.
Dash, far too many.
On the other hand, I am proud to recall that we tried to have each candidate visit with exactly the same groups of appropriate
individuals relating to veterinary medicine, such as faculty, staff, fellow deans, students, and some that include
graduates of veterinary medicine on some of those groups.
Similarly, I tried to ensure that each group asked the same questions of each candidate and that where possible
The sessions were held in the same room and the same sequence for each of the candidates.
Paragraph.
Finally, when the lengthy process of reviewing an octet
of visitors was completed.
I then went back to each interview group and asked them to rank all of the interviewees in a weighted tally fashion.
When that calculation was completed, it was clear that two individuals were far ahead of the others in the evaluation process.
One had been dean at
Ohio State for perhaps two years recently, but had then left in a huff, apparently having told some of the campus leadership where they could go and what they could do when they got there.
To me, this man seemed exciting.
Some of his ideas relating to A&M's veterinary medical potential seemed highly innovative, and others, while imaginative, were clearly controversial.
The word, quote, exciting, quote, seemed to jump into my evaluation of it.
The other leader was a native Texan and graduate of A&M, George Shelton, then the Associate Dean of Veterinary Medicine at the University
of Missouri.
By comparison with the other frontrunner, Dr. Shelton was comparatively reserved, quiet, always composed,
pleasant and would obviously never provoke any camp any great upheaval paragraph thus when i reviewed the two front runners when i reviewed the search process
first with Vice President Calhoun, and then Dr. Williams.
I indicated that the former dean of Ohio State would be, quote, exciting, yet there might often be upheaval and controversy.

things quote would never but quote things would never be dull period quote after giving that evaluation to president williams he asked me to write the other man and i told him that dr shelton seemed to be a an individual
who would calmly, quietly, carefully, and consistently lead veterinary medicine to improvement and higher achievement.
Without any delay, he said, let's go with Shelton.
I've got enough damn excitement in my life already.
I need peace and quiet wherever we can find it.
After the Shelton's moved to College Station.

The football and basketball season tickets for the Shelton's and the Monroe's were side by side.

In both those sports.
We became good friends.

When the search committee was seeking a new chancellor at the University of Missouri,
In 1987, the president of the Missouri Alumni Association served on the search committee.
He, a very highly regarded lawyer and future state senator,
noticed that one of the finalists had served for a number of years, had served for more than two decades at Texas A&M.
Thus, he picked up the phone and called
a man who had held an office adjoining that of his father in the College of Veteran Medicine at Missouri for a number of years.
He asked this man, whom he had
referred to as Uncle George, quote, because when this future MU alum leader was growing up, he would visit with George Shilton while he was waiting for his father.
Thus, when Uncle George gave very positive evaluations of the former dean of faculties at A&M, that evaluation was given a high rating by the
Missouri alumni leader and his search committee colleagues.
Another paragraph, another search here that had a
more complicated process was the attempt to replace Ed Romanek when he retired.
A number of individuals were were sought and I believe that
Dr. Winerdi was the coordinator of that search.
But I certainly was involved a great deal.
Finally, we identified a man from the University of Arizona who seemed very, very promising.
and related that evaluation to Dr. Calhoun, who then directed us to proceed and quote, hire him regardless of the salary we have to offer, period, quote.
with optimism in our efforts.
When Erdi and I chatted with the Arizona prospect on the phone, finally found a salary that he would accept and went back to Dr. Calhoun to report our success.
only to be stunned at his decision that we had gone too high and that we should go back and reduce the salary or terminate the offer, which we had to do.
In hindsight, I shall always wonder what would have been the result if that very promising man had been located.
Another search was for the director of university libraries.
and included a wide variety of interviewees, including probably the first black candidate at such a high administrative level on the campus, along with a highly capable woman.
Once more, when Erdi and I were together in the effort, and when we summarized the process, we urged that the black man
who had been very successful at the University of Houston, be our target without any hint at all of any racial reason for his evaluation.
Calhoun directed us to proceed to recruit the woman, Dr. Irene Hoadley, who was the number three person in the administrative hierarchy at Ohio State University.
Ironically, the man would be that we
failed to pursue would be selected as the director of libraries at one of the great Ivy League schools a year or so later.
One of the most memorable searches for me
occurred at A&M, occurred just a few months, a few weeks before we moved to the task of president at University of Texas at El Paso.
This was search for a new dean of education because Frank Hubert
had moved up to chancellor of the Texas A&M system.
By then, I felt somewhat, I felt experienced in dean searches and we were able to proceed with the process of
similar questions as a part of a uniform schedule and an emphasis that each member of every interview group would attempt to
make direct personal contacts with individuals that they knew well who might be able to evaluate this individual.
That practice had come as a result of our becoming convinced that written letters of evaluation
from the applicant or nominee's references usually contain nothing but glowing praise.
Further inquiries to individuals that were unknown, who were strangers,
to A&M inquirers sometimes resulted in meaningless or even unreliable information.
Thus
I always tried to emphasize the essentiality of contacting individuals known directly.
Another matter of emphasis
in the search processes which I could affect was to urge that an effort be made to find out why an apparently highly capable individual would be willing
to consider another appointment?
Or, in other words, was this individual needing to find another slot because they were about to lose the one they had?
Paragraph, in the search for a new dean of education, that became a reality.
regarding two of the key candidates.
One of the interviewees arrived on the campus
a couple of hours after my wife and I returned to College Station from our three-day on-campus visit and interview sessions
